data.text: Contents
Procedures for requesting a Consultant to cover unforeseen emergency duties ......... 6
Introduction

The  Trust  recognises  that  under  their  current  terms  and  conditions  of  service Consultants  are  not  contractually  obliged  to  ‘act  down'  /  cover  unforeseen circumstances or to be compulsorily resident on-call to cover the duties of more junior medical staff, except in the most extraordinary and unforeseeable circumstances. As such, underpinning the whole of this protocol is the desire to avoid implementing this system wherever possible. The protocol should only be invoked when there is no alternative safe system to provide on-site medical support for patients, and excludes a declared major incident.
A consultant's agreement to act down at any time is voluntary and they may accept or decline the request without detriment.

Day time absences should be covered by specific departmental contingency plans maintaining  standards  of  clinical  care  and  prioritising  what  work  will  be  safely undertaken with resources available.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Outline the actions that should be taken to minimise the need for consultants to cover emergency unforeseen duties.
Agree the arrangements for requesting a Consultant to cover such duties.
Outline the remuneration/compensation arrangements for individuals who cover emergency unforeseen duties.
Definitions

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Joint Local negotiating Committee (JLNC) has the duty to monitor the operation of this policy and to review this policy prior to its renewal date
The Site Medical Director: will require from the Clinical Director a brief report as to why the acting down / cover was necessary.

Clinical Director/ General Manager/ Senior Manager on call: to request a consultant to cover an unforeseen duty as appropriate. It is the responsibility of the on-call manager or night coordinator, not the on-call Consultant to obtain suitable locum / bank medical cover.

Consultant on call for specialty: is the judge of if it is safe for the department to continue to operate. Following a period of covering unforeseen duties , the consultant must obtain the appropriate form from Doctors Bank/ Clinical Directorate.
Measures to avoid unforeseen duties
Consultants are usually requested to cover unforeseen duties due to a shortage or absence of junior staff. The majority of such absences or shortages are known well in advance.

Doctors are required to give a minimum of six weeks' notice of any requested leave and internal cover is arranged, co-ordinated by the Clinical Lead / Director or their nominee to assure adequate levels of cover are provided. The majority of junior doctors now participate in rotas, which contractually require them to prospectively cover the annual leave and study leave of their colleagues who participate in the same rota. Clinical lead / Directors or designated deputies should ensure that they have arrangements in place for the management of these rotas. There should also be a mechanism for identifying at the earliest opportunity any problems whereby locum cover may be necessary. Where the need for locum cover is identified and agreed this should be conveyed to the rota co- ordinator

Where the need for bank cover is identified and agreed this should be conveyed to the Trust bank and managed via Locums Nest. Where a doctor requests a period of leave for which bank cover is required giving less than six weeks' notice this should be discussed with the Clinical lead / Director or designated deputy and any approval of the leave should be conditional upon being able to find appropriate cover. Leave requests should only be approved by the Clinical Lead / Director.

From time to time certain specialties encounter difficulties in recruiting to their agreed quota of junior doctor posts. Clinical Lead / Directors should again ensure that mechanisms are in place to identify potential problems at the earliest opportunity enlisting the support and advice of Staff Bank to try and make temporary arrangements for cover with the Trust Bank (Locum Nest).

Although the majority of leave can be planned well in advance there will be occasions where absences occur at very short notice because of unforeseen circumstances such as sickness, domestic crisis or the failure of a planned locum to arrive. Inevitably absences occurring in these situations are much more difficult to contend with. There are, however, certain measures which can be put in place to assist in the management of these situations as described below.

Directorates should ensure that junior doctors are fully aware of the local procedure for reporting sickness absence, the person they should report to, and the need for absence to be reported at the earliest opportunity. If locum cover is required the appropriate Consultant should be informed of the position and be advised of the attempts being made to find cover. The early notification of absence maximises the amount of time that the Clinical Lead /Director/General Manager, with the assistance of the Trust bank, have to find appropriate locum cover if necessary. This allows the Consultant the maximum notification of a potential problem allowing him or her to start to form contingency plans.

It may be possible for other junior doctors in the hospital to provide bank cover however, this arrangement should only be used to cover short term unforeseeable absences. It must be recognised that these duties are outside the contractual hours of the doctor concerned and remuneration at the Trust bank rate will be applied. It must also be recognised that such an arrangement has implications for trainee doctor's hours of duty which are subject to certain restrictions by their terms and conditions of service. Thus the arrangement should only be utilised when other measures have been exhausted or there is insufficient time to implement other methods of providing cover.
The failure of a locum to turn up is often discovered outside of the normal 9.00 a.m. –

p.m. Monday to Friday hours. There may also be other absences which are notified outside of normal hours, for example the junior doctor who is due to commence his or her on-call duties at 9.00 a.m. on Saturday morning but falls ill during Friday night. These are by far the most difficult situations in which to find alternative cover. In this situation the on-call Consultant for the Specialty concerned should be informed at the earliest opportunity and their advice sought. It is the responsibility of the on-call manager or night coordinator, not the on-call Consultant to obtain suitable locum medical cover, however, the on-call Consultant would be expected to support the on-call manager as appropriate in their endeavours.
Frequency

5.9.1  If more than two episodes of consultants acting down occur within a 6 month period within a single speciality, this will be notified to the Site Associate Director of HR and a workforce review will be offered to the Directorate which will be conducted by the directorate management team with support of the HR / Medical Workforce team.
Procedures for requesting a Consultant to cover unforeseen
emergency duties
It will be the responsibility of the Clinical Director / General Manager to ask a Consultant to cover unforeseen duties.

Only where there is no alternative safe system to provide on-site medical support for patients, and excluding a major incident, will the Clinical Director, General Manager or Senior Manager on-call ask a consultant to cover junior duties. This request and authorisation should be confirmed in writing/email, and then a summary provided to the Site Medical Director.

It is recognised that the Consultant on-call for the specialty concerned is the ultimate judge of whether a department can continue to operate safely. Any decision to close a department must take account of the implications for patients, staff, any knock on effect for other specialties and any effect for other Trusts, together with an assessment by the Consultant of his/her own ability to provide safe cover. If the impact or risk of closing a department is greater than keeping the department open then it cannot be closed. If potential problems are identified during normal working hours and an alternative being considered is the closure of the department this must be discussed initially with the on- call Manager and through him/her with the on-call Director and/or Medical Director.

Consultant staff will not be asked to cover junior duties unless it is as the result of an unforeseen event, which would put the well-being of patients at significant risk. In this situation the consultant- in-charge recognises that he/she has the professional responsibility for a patient admitted under their care or the delegated responsibility for the patient admitted to the care of Consultant colleagues if participating in an on-call rota. It should not be automatically assumed that a consultant can perform all the tasks and procedures that the junior staff currently undertake. There may be a lack of familiarity with IT systems or with practical procedures such as pacing, cannulation, central venous access and many others. To allow for this, clinical directorates will make appropriate contingency plans for each specialty rota, detailing the responsibilities of any Consultant who is asked to act down for that rota. Irrespective of these arrangements, any Consultant who does not believe they can safely ‘act down' and perform particular duties will not be compelled to do so. In this case they, or whoever is asking them to act down, must speak to their colleagues and/or their Clinical Director so that alternative arrangements can be made; these could include reorganising responsibilities with other medical staff in the department who are on duty or reorganising responsibilities with other departments. A record must be made of any alternative arrangements made.

The Trust recognises that under their current terms and conditions of service Consultants are not contractually obliged to ‘act down' / cover unforeseen circumstances or to be compulsorily resident on-call to cover the duties of more junior medical staff, except in the most extraordinary and unforeseeable circumstances.
Remuneration for unforeseen duties

Where a consultant agrees to cover an unforeseen duty to cover a junior and is on call, the Clinical Directorate can request that a second consultant is found to cover the first consultant's on-call. This must be justified, the second consultant covering the off site on call will be remunerated at prevailing internal MSE bank rates for non –resident on call.

Where a consultant acts down for a period between 19.00 and 07.00 or at a weekend or bank holidays (unless this forms part of his/her standard sessional commitment) and is required to either be resident on-call or participates in a shift system he/she will be
remunerated at the rate of three PAs (at their personal PA rate) for every one PA on duty (one programmed activity equates to 3 hours between 19.00 and 07.00 or at weekends).

Alternatively, the Consultant may request time off in lieu for this period. Time will be calculated at the rate of three PAs for each PA on duty. This time should be taken within 6 months of the period on-call and should be agreed with the Clinical Director in order to ensure appropriate cover is in place.

Following  a  period  of  covering  junior  duties  the  Consultant  must  complete  the appropriate form (appendix 1) this needs to be approved by the Site Medical Director. The Site Medical Director will require the Clinical Director concerned to produce a brief report as to why the acting down was necessary and what measures were taken to avoid it.
Compensatory Rest
7.5.1 Following a period of resident on-call, Consultants will not be expected to work the next day and may take this time off as compensatory rest.

7.5.2 Every attempt should be made not to disrupt the service and where the Consultant considers it not practical to take the following day off as compensatory rest this should be taken as soon as is reasonably practical and in any case within 7 days of the period on-call.

7.5.3 The compensatory rest should be taken adjacent to another period of daily or weekly rest and will be equal to the number of hours undertaken as “resident on-call” up to a maximum of 1 working day.

7.5.4 Ideally that point at which compensatory rest is taken should be agreed between the Consultant and the Clinical Director; preferably at the point the request to act down is made. However, in all cases it is the responsibility of the consultant to determine for themselves their fitness to work safely immediately after a period of resident on-call and where they do not take compensatory rest immediately, their continuing fitness to work safely prior to taking a period of compensatory rest.
Training Requirements
No specific training requirements.

It is the author's responsibility to inform the JLNC of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
